help.p: This self-assessment questionnaire generates an open data certificate and badge you can publish to tell people all about this open data. We also use your answers to learn how organisations publish open data.
When you answer these questions it demonstrates your efforts to comply with relevant legislation. You should also check which other laws and policies apply to your sector or jurisdiction.
You do not need to answer all the questions to earn a certificate. Just answer those you can.

group.label: Rights
group.help: your right to share this data with people

question.label: Do you have the rights to publish this data as open data?

option.label: yes, you have the rights to publish this data as open data
option.requirement: You should have a clear legal right to publish this data.

option.label: no, you don’t have the rights to publish this data as open data
you’re not sure if you have the rights to publish this data as open data
the rights in this data are complicated or unclear

question.help: If your organisation didn't originally create or gather this data then you might not have the right to publish it. If you’re not sure, check with the data owner because you will need their permission to publish it.

if.requirement: You must have the right to publish this data.

question.display: Risks in using this data are described at
question.label: Where do you detail the risks people might encounter if they use this data?
question.help: It can be risky for people to use data without a clear legal right to do so. For example, the data might be taken down in response to a legal challenge. Give a URL for a page that describes the risk of using this data.
question.requirement: You should document risks associated with using this data, so people can work out how they want to use it.

question.label: Was the data originally created or generated by you?

option.display: originally created or generated by its curator
option.label: yes

question.help: If any part of this data was sourced outside your organisation by other individuals or organisations then you need to give extra information about your right to publish it.

question.label: Was some of this data extracted or calculated from other data?
question.help: An extract or smaller part of someone else's data still means your rights to use it might be affected. There might also be legal issues if you analysed their data to produce new results from it.

if.requirement: You indicated that this data wasn't originally created or gathered by you, and wasn't crowdsourced, so it must have been extracted or calculated from other data sources.

question.label: Are all sources of this data already published as open data?
question.help: You're allowed to republish someone else's data if it's already under an open data licence or if their rights have expired or been waived. If any part of this data is not like this then you'll need legal advice before you can publish it.

if.requirement: You should get legal advice to make sure you have the right to publish this data.

question.label: Was some of this data crowdsourced?
question.help: If the data includes information contributed by people outside your organisation, you need their permission to publish their contributions as open data.

if.requirement: You indicated that the data wasn't originally created or gathered by you, and wasn't extracted or calculated from other data, so it must have been crowdsourced.

question.label: Did contributors to this data use their judgement?
question.help: If people used their creativity or judgement to contribute data then they have copyright over their work. For example, writing a description or deciding whether or not to include some data in a dataset would require judgement. So contributors must transfer or waive their rights, or license the data to you before you can publish it.

question.display: The contributor licence or waiver is at
question.label: Where is the contributor licence or waiver?
question.help: Provide a link to a licence or waiver that shows contributors allow you to reuse their data. The agreement will either transfer contributor's rights to you, waive their rights, or license the data to you so you can publish it.

question.label: Have all contributors agreed to the contributor licence or waiver?
question.help: Check all contributors agree to a contributor licence or waiver before you reuse or republish their contributions. You should keep a record of who gave contributions and whether or not they agree to the contributor licence or waiver.
question.requirement: You must get contributors to agree to a contributor licence or waiver that gives you the right to publish their work as open data.

question.display: The sources of this data are described at
question.label: Where do you describe sources of this data?
question.help: Provide a URL that documents where the data was sourced from (its provenance) and the rights under which you publish the data. This helps people understand where the data comes from.
question.requirement: You should document where the data came from and the rights under which you publish it, so people are assured they can use the parts of the data provided by third parties.

question.label: Is documentation about the sources of this data also in machine-readable format?

yesno.yes: machine-readable data about the sources of this data

question.help: Information about data sources should be human-readable so people can understand it, as well as in a metadata format that computers can process. When everyone does this it helps other people find out how the same open data is being used and justify its ongoing publication.
question.requirement: You should include machine-readable data about the sources of this data.

group.label: Licensing
group.help: how you give people permission to use this data

question.label: Where have you published the rights statement for this dataset?
question.help: Give the URL to a page that describes the right to re-use this dataset. This should include a reference to its license, attribution requirements, and a statement about relevant copyright and database rights. A rights statement helps people understand what they can and can't do with the data.
question.requirement: You should publish a rights statement that details copyright, database rights, licensing and how people should give attribution to the data.

question.label: Is there any copyright in the content of this data?

option.display: no rights in the content of the data
option.label: no, the data only contains facts and numbers
option.help: There is no copyright in factual information. If the data does not contain any content that was created through intellectual effort, there are no rights in the content.

option.display: content rights in the data held by one person or organisation
option.label: yes, and the rights are all held by the same person or organisation
option.help: Choose this option if the content in the data was all created by or transferred to the same person or organisation.

option.display: content rights in data held by different people or organisations
option.label: yes, and the rights are held by different people or organisations
option.help: In some data, the rights in different records are held by different people or organisations. Information about rights needs to be kept in the data too.

question.label: Is the content of the data marked as public domain?
question.help: Works in the public domain are those whose intellectual property rights have expired, have been forfeited, or are inapplicable. If none of the content of your data have copyright or other rights over it, it is good practice to explicitly state this by labelling it as ‘public domain’. You can do this by using the Creative Commons Public Domain Mark.
question.requirement: You should mark public domain content as public domain so that people know they can reuse it.

question.label: Under which licence can others reuse content?
question.help: Remember that whoever spends intellectual effort creating content automatically gets rights over it but creative content does not include facts. So people need a waiver or a licence which proves that they can use the content and explains how they can do that legally. Common licenses are listed here; if there is no copyright in the content, it's expired, or you've waived copyright, choose 'Not applicable'.

question.display: The content in this data is not licensed because
question.label: Why doesn't a licence apply to the content of the data?

option.label: there is no copyright in the content of this data
option.help: Copyright only applies to content if you spent intellectual effort creating it, for example, by writing text that's within the data. There's no copyright if the content only contains facts.

option.label: copyright has expired
option.help: Copyright lasts for a fixed amount of time, based on either the number of years after the death of its creator or its publication. You should check when the content was created or published because if that was a long time ago, copyright might have expired.

option.label: copyright has been waived
option.help: This means no one owns copyright and anyone can do whatever they want with this data.

question.label: Which waiver do you use to waive copyright?
question.help: You need a statement to show people you've done this, so they understand that they can do whatever they like with this data. Standard waivers already exist like CCZero but you can write your own with legal advice.

question.label: Where is the waiver for the copyright?
question.help: Give a URL to your own publicly available waiver so people can check that it does waive your copyright.

question.label: What's the name of the licence?
question.help: If you use a different licence, we need its name so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate.

question.label: Where is the licence?
question.help: Give a URL to the licence, so people can see it on your Open Data Certificate and check that it's publicly available.

question.label: Is the licence an open licence?
question.help: If you aren't sure what an open licence is then read the Open Definition by Open Knowledge International. Next, choose your licence from the Open Definition Advisory Board open licence list. If a licence isn't in their list, it's either not open or hasn't been assessed yet.
question.requirement: You must publish open data under an open licence so that people can use it.

question.display: The rights and licensing of the content are explained at
question.label: Where are the rights and licensing of the content explained?
question.help: Give the URL for a page where you describe how someone can find out the rights and licensing of a piece of content from the data.

question.display: The rights statement includes data about
question.label: Does your rights statement include machine-readable versions of

option.label: content licence
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the licence for the content of this data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: attribution text
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the text to use when citing the data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: attribution URL
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the URL to link to when citing this data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: copyright notice or statement
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the copyright statement or notice of this data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: copyright year
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the copyright year for the data, so automatic tools can use it.

option.label: copyright holder
option.requirement: You should provide machine-readable data in your rights statement about the copyright holder for the data, so automatic tools can use it.

question.help: It's good practice to embed information about rights in machine-readable formats so people can automatically attribute this data back to you when they use it.

question.label: Is this data is about people or their activities?

option.label: no, the data is not about people or their activities
option.help: Remember that individuals can still be identified even if data isn't directly about them. For example, road traffic flow data combined with an individual's commuting patterns could reveal information about that person.

option.label: yes, there is a risk that individuals can be identified, for example by third parties with access to extra information
option.help: Some data is legitimately about individuals like civil service pay or public expenses for example.

question.label: Has the data is about individuals been de-identified?

option.label: yes, the data been de-identified
option.help: Remember that individuals can still be identified even if data isn't directly about them. For example, road traffic flow data combined with an individual's commuting patterns could reveal information about that person.

option.label: no, there is a risk that individuals can be identified, for example by third parties with access to extra information
option.help: The law may permit some data about individuals to be published online.

question.label: Do you have permission to publish this personal data online?
question.help: You may be able to publish data about individuals online if either, the data is required or permitted to be published by law, or you have permission from the affected individuals.
question.requirement: You should publish a rights statement that details copyright, database rights, licensing and how people should give attribution to the data.

question.display: The right to publish this data about individuals is documented at
question.label: Where do you document your right to publish data about individuals?
question.requirement: You should document your right to publish data about individuals for people who use your data and for those affected by disclosure.

question.label: Has your de-identification process been independently audited?
question.requirement: You should have your de-identification process audited independently to ensure it reduces the risk of individuals being reidentified.

question.label: Have you assessed the privacy risks of publishing this data?

yesno.yes: assessed the privacy risks of publishing this data
yesno.no: not assessed the privacy risks of publishing this data

question.help: You should assess the likelihood of personal data being disclosed and the consequences to individuals of the disclosure.
question.requirement: You should assess the privacy risks if you publish data about individuals.

question.display: The privacy risk assessment is published at
question.label: Where is your privacy risk assessment published?
question.help: Provide a URL to where people can check how you have assessed the privacy risks to individuals. This may be redacted or summarised if it contains sensitive information.
question.requirement: You should publish your privacy risk assessment so people can understand how you have assessed the risks of disclosing data.

question.display: The privacy risk assessment has been
question.label: Has your privacy risk assessment been independently audited?
question.help: It's good practice to check your assessment was done correctly. Independent audits by specialists or third-parties tend to be more rigorous and impartial.
question.requirement: You should have your privacy risk assessment audited independently to ensure it has been carried out correctly.

question.label: Are you prepared to respond if publishing this data compromises the privacy of individuals?
